image.altText: buses in a depot

props.synopsis: The ACT government will ask the Fair Work Commission to order bus drivers back to work. The union says the strike is due to drivers being assaulted.

title.children: 'A bag of fish heads poured on them': Canberra bus drivers strike over rate of assaults

image.altText: A sign outside a tertiary education campus

props.synopsis: A consultant whose $5 million contract with the Canberra's Institute of Technology (CIT) was cancelled wins his battle to sue the organisation.

title.children: Consultant who sued CIT for breach of contract is awarded $2.4 million by Canberra court

image.altText: A woman in a blue dress smiles while holding up a glass award.

props.synopsis: The co-founder of an organisation helping children experiencing serious injury or illness avoid missing out on school, Megan Gilmour, is named 2025 Australian of the Year for the ACT.

title.children: After Megan's son missed over a year of school while chronically ill she promised not to turn her back on others like him

image.altText: The outside of a building with a large "Canberra Hospital'' sign.

props.synopsis: Canberra Health Services walks back a proposal to block non-ACT residents from accessing specialist medical appointments at the Canberra Hospital, as part of its plan to reduce massive patient backlogs.

title.children: Low category patients on dermatology waitlist 'unlikely' to be seen, ACT health minister concedes

image.altText: An exterior shot of an ANU building.

props.synopsis: An Australian National University associate professor sharply criticises Australia's domestic intelligence agency, saying it asked her to report on Chinese international students and put a "chill" on China research as the bilateral relationship deteriorated.

title.children: 'Atmosphere of fear': Academic says spy agency asked her to report on Chinese students

image.altText: A blue sign saying Queanbeyan District Health Service sits at the entrance to the carpark of a hospital

props.synopsis: Two new clinics providing abortion services are set to be established in Queanbeyan and NSW's south coast. It comes after an ABC investigation exposed that Queanbeyan Hospital had ceased providing surgical terminations.

title.children: Surgical abortions at Queanbeyan Hospital to be reinstated

image.altText: A high school aged boy in a grey t-shirt and navy New York Yankees cap smiles.

props.synopsis: It's up to state and territory governments to fund media literacy programs in schools, and a 2023 study of young Australians found only one in four surveyed received a lesson teaching them how to work out if news stories are true in the past year.

title.children: Aaron is in year 11 and recently quit Instagram. He thinks others should do the same

image.altText: An elderly man with grey hair and a moustache.

props.synopsis: A coronial inquest into the disappearance of Peter Claux, who went missing on a dog walk on the NSW far south coast, has found he likely died in thick vegetation in a national park a short distance from his car.

title.children: Inquest hears elderly man likely died in South Coast bushland walking dog

image.altText: A woman wearing sunglasses and clutching a designer handbag lies on a sun loung and waves a hand and a leg in the air

props.synopsis: There is a list of high-profile Trump loyalists who will land positions in his White House, but this week Mar-a-Lago was crawling with other MAGA faithful who want a presidential treat too.

title.children: A TV host as the boss of the Pentagon, Musk making recommendations on spending. This is Trump's White House

image.altText: A man wearing a suit

props.synopsis: President-elect Donald Trump has nominated Robert F Kennedy Jr to serve in his cabinet as the head of the Department of Health and Human Services.

title.children: Trump nominates vaccine sceptic Robert F Kennedy Jr to lead US federal health agency

image.altText: Two men in a suit at a press conference

props.synopsis: The Albanese government is pushing for the biggest shake-up of funding and disclosure laws in more than a decade.

title.children: Labor unveils its plan to end political 'arms race', with clamps on Clive Palmer, Climate 200

image.altText: A man wearing a suit and tie stands talking in front of a stand with five news microphones.

props.synopsis: Former SA opposition leader David Speirs appears in court for the first time since being charged with drug offences.

title.children: Bail conditions allow ex-SA opposition leader David Speirs to travel overseas following drug charge

image.altText: A group of people watching from the street as a plume of smoke rises from behind an apartment building.

props.synopsis: An Israeli government minister says the country is close to a deal that would see fighting cease in Lebanon, but only if it is granted powers to respond to any Hezbollah incursions.

title.children: Israel and Hezbollah are ready for a truce, but a major sticking point remains

image.altText: A screenshot from a website listing a tractor for sale with a giant red FAKE stamp on top

props.synopsis: These farmers bought used tractors from a website that looked like the real deal. Instead, they fell into a trap laid by scammers using a Russian-linked website to pose as a legitimate Sydney-based business.

title.children: At least three Australian farmers have fallen victim to a sophisticated tractor scam

image.altText: Two women look at a share price board outside the ASX in Sydney.

props.synopsis: The Australian share market has opened higher, mining giant Mineral Resources says companies linked to Chris Ellison's daughter were asked to repay $158,000, and Jerome Powell says the Fed is in no rush to lower rates. Follow live.

title.children: ASX higher, US Fed not in a 'hurry' to cut rates and MinRes reveals financial benefit to founder's daughter

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Another forecaster pushes rate cut expectations back to May
ASX rises 0.5pc as healthcare stocks and Mineral Resources weigh on share market

image.altText: Brightly rainbow coloured fireworks are seen over the Opera House in Sydney, Australia

props.synopsis: The "Digital Duty of Care" has the potential to be the most meaningful change to online safety laws in Australian history — even if it doesn't exactly go viral, writes national technology reporter Ange Lavoipierre.

title.children: Confused about the government's latest social media policy? It might help to think about fireworks

image.altText: A photo from the show of three men sitting inside a truck.

props.synopsis: With authentic one-liners like "shut ya hole" and plenty of other relatable moments in the Australian Outback, the new Netflix series Territory has generated over 15 million views.

title.children: 'How not to do a Jamie Oliver': Netflix series Territory went where many shows were 'not brave enough'

image.altText: Mohamed Al Fayed wears a blue pin-stripped suit looking neutrally below the camera's line

props.synopsis: The three women have told the BBC that they were also assaulted by both Mohamed Al Fayed and Salah Fayed, with one alleging she was raped.

title.children: Mohamed Al Fayed's brother accused of sexually assaulting three former Harrods store workers

image.altText: Bear suit

props.synopsis: A bear caught on camera breaking into luxury cars in the mountains east of Los Angeles was "clearly a human in a bear suit", according to the California Department of Insurance.

title.children: Insurers say a 'bear' that damaged luxury cars in California was 'clearly a human in a bear suit'

image.altText: Infowars founder Alex Jones looking sideways, wearing a suit.

props.synopsis: Alex Jones owes $1.5 billion after defaming the families of those killed in the 2012 Sandy Hook Elementary School shootings, claiming it was a hoax staged by crisis actors.

title.children: The Onion buys conspiracy website Infowars after $1.5b ruling against founder Alex Jones

image.altText: A Bluey Christmas window display.

props.synopsis: A pro-Palestinian protest outside the Myer windows "will not go ahead" after the department store cancelled Sunday's official unveiling of its popular Christmas display due to the planned disruption.

title.children: Planned pro-Palestinian protest 'will not go ahead' after Myer cancels unveiling of Christmas windows

image.altText: A graduate holds on to his hat while talking on his mobile phone

props.synopsis: New research reveals senior academics at Australian universities favoured white prospective PhD students. These students say their experiences echo the findings.

title.children: PhD graduates back study indicating racist bias among academics at Australian universities

image.altText: Young blonde man taking a selfie in an elevator. He is smiling and doing a peace sign with hand.

props.synopsis: When your sense of your own identity gets attached to your job, how do you move on when you're let go? Studies suggest younger workers are more likely than older people to be sacked or made redundant. So what should you do if this happens to you?

title.children: 'Am I just young and stupid?' Young Australians on being made redundant

image.altText: Silhouette of a car in front of a building fire.

props.synopsis: Police say a string of fiery ram raids on tobacconists in northern NSW is part of a nation-wide turf war in the illicit tobacco racket.

title.children: Thieves allegedly try to run over witness to fiery tobacco ram raids linked to national 'turf wars'

image.altText: Tourists take part in a white water rafting trip.

props.synopsis: Tour guides have been added to the national Occupation Shortage List for the first time enabling foreign workers with specific skills to fill labour shortages.

title.children: International workers show visitors around Australia as tour guide shortage hits crisis point

image.altText: Smiling Caucasian man with dark closely cropped hair, beard, wears black tee with logo stands at a bar.

props.synopsis: As the NSW government inquires into the loneliness crisis, this man would like to see community groups empowered to connect people.

title.children: Mental illness survivor helps other connects as state probes loneliness crisis

image.altText: An aerial view of a round mine shaft opening in rocky terrain, with eight white vehivles parked nearby

props.synopsis: The South African government says it will not help a group of illegal miners inside a closed mine in the country's North West province who have been denied access to basic supplies as part of an official strategy against illegal mining.

title.children: Hundreds of miners denied water underground as South African government moves to 'smoke out' illegal migrants

image.altText: An older man smiles at a baby

props.synopsis: Three months after he disappeared, the family of William Wadsworth are desperate to know what happened to the 76-year-old Vietnam veteran and, as the days go by, they believe foul play should not be ruled out.

title.children: 'Friendly' Vietnam vet still missing months after checking in to country caravan park

image.altText: A car boot full of groceries.

props.synopsis: As wet season looms in northern Australia, the stockpiling of food in pantries and freezers is underway. Here's how the experts prepare for the big wet.

title.children: This grazier's shopping list hasn't changed much since 1986 — 34kg of flour, 26kg of sugar, four litres of tomato sauce

image.altText: Nick Kyrgios smiles while holding a microphone on court before interviewing a player at the Australian Open.

props.synopsis: Nick Kyrgios has confirmed he will make his long-awaited return to competitive tennis at the Brisbane International after playing only one tour match in more than two years.

title.children: 'Going to be sick': Kyrgios confirms tennis return via Australian tournament after injury nightmare

image.altText: Elon Mus raises his fist as Donald Trump speaks at the podium

props.synopsis: It's that time of the week again. Think you've been paying attention to the news?

title.children: Weekly news quiz: Musk goes into politics for real, a koala sneaks inside and the prestigious Booker Prize

image.altText: A hand can be seen in the foreground holding a bottle and a dropper full of THC oil. Marijuana buds are surrounding the bottle.

props.synopsis: Medicinal marijuana has been legal in Australia for several years now, but when could an employee lose their job for testing positive for the drug in the workplace?

title.children: The repercussions of medicinal marijuana use in Australian workplaces

image.altText: An adult lies in a hospital bed.

props.synopsis: A new report by the Australian Institute of Health and Welfare reveals the major causes of injury hospitalisation and deaths, delving deeper into four major areas to identify current trends and changes throughout the past decade.

title.children: Australians are tripping, stumbling and falling off scooters — here's what the latest hospitalisation data tells us

image.altText: Two small fish with silvery blue scales and red colouring.

props.synopsis: The largest survey of Australia's freshwater fish suggests about one third should be listed as threatened species.

title.children: 'Ring the alarm bells': Study finds 35 fish species should be added to threatened species list
